item.title: U.K. Markets Slump Despite Kwasi Kwarteng’s Ouster
item.description: Kwasi Kwarteng, the chancellor of the Exchequer, was fired on Friday by Prime Minister Liz Truss in a bid to end weeks of market turmoil.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Isabel Infantes/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Kwasi Kwarteng, the former chancellor of the Exchequer.

item.title: How the U.K. Finance Minister Came to Ignore Finance Experts
item.description: Kwasi Kwarteng, the chancellor of the Exchequer, faces widespread anger over the tax cuts he and Liz Truss have pushed, but their history of dismissing the economic establishment goes back years.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Tolga Akmen/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Kwasi Kwarteng, Britain’s chancellor of the Exchequer, announced a series of tax cuts that sent the markets spiraling.

item.title: Russia Says It Will Evacuate Civilians From Kherson Amid Ukrainian Gains
item.description: The announcement seemed timed to deflect attention from Russian forces who, since Monday, have killed more than three dozen Ukrainians in a barrage of missile strikes on towns and cities.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents of the Kherson region of Ukraine near Mykolaivka on Sunday.

item.title: Elon Musk Says SpaceX Can’t Fund Starlink Internet Service in Ukraine ‘Indefinitely’
item.description: Starlink terminals have been critical in allowing the Ukrainian military to coordinate on the battlefield, including in recent offensives.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd and Helene Cooper
item.media:credit: Matt Rourke/Associated Press

item.title: French Refineries Strike May Presage a Winter of Discontent for Europe
item.description: Bitten by inflation, workers are demanding a greater share of the surging profits of energy giants. It’s the kind of unrest leaders fear as they struggle to keep a united front against Russia.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter and Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Outside the Total refinery in Gonfreville-l’Orcher, just outside of Le Havre, France, on Thursday, union members burned wood pallets, hoisted flags and voted to continue a strike.

item.title: Xi Jinping, China’s Leader, Embodies His Authoritarian Era
item.description: Xi Jinping was first cast as a firm but genial leader with a common touch. Approaching a second decade in power, he looms over China like a stern Communist monarch.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:credit: Thomas Peter/Reuters
item.media:description: Xi Jinping on a giant screen at an event last year in Beijing’s National Stadium to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the founding of the Communist Party of China.

item.title: China’s Internet Censors Race to Quell Beijing Protest Chatter
item.description: Some search terms were banned, WeChat accounts suspended and songs removed to stop discussion of a rare public protest denouncing Xi Jinping.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi and Claire Fu
item.media:credit: Dake Kang/Associated Press
item.media:description: An intersection near a Beijing bridge, where social media videos appeared to show smoke and protest banners on Thursday. Covid-19 policies were among the criticisms raised.

item.title: Jan. 6 Panel Vividly Detailed the Attack. Accountability Is Another Matter.
item.description: Over its nine public hearings, the committee has not moved the needle of public opinion of former President Donald J. Trump. But it may have laid the groundwork for criminal prosecution.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack

item.title: Jan. 6 Panel Votes to Subpoena Trump as It Wraps Up Its Case
item.description: “He must be accountable,” the committee’s chairman said as it presented a sweeping summation of its findings. But the prospect of the former president testifying appeared unlikely.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater and Alan Feuer
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: The House Jan. 6 committee on Thursday put former President Donald J. Trump at the center of a sprawling effort to maintain his grip on power that began even before Election Day.

item.title: Supreme Court Rejects Trump Request to Intervene in Documents Case
item.description: Without any noted dissents, the court issued a one-sentence statement that amounted to a rebuke to the former president.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:credit: Bridget Bennett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump has often been infuriated by what he sees as a lack of deference to him by the Supreme Court, to which he has appointed three justices.

item.title: 5 Killed as Gunman Strikes Raleigh, N.C., Neighborhood
item.description: An off-duty police officer was among those killed in the attack. At least two other people were wounded, including another officer.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cataneo and Rick Rojas
item.media:credit: Ethan Hyman/The News & Observer, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Dozens of law enforcement vehicles rushed to the scene of what the authorities called an “active shooter” in Raleigh, N.C., on Thursday.

item.title: The Golden Age of Dispensary Interior Design Is Almost Here
item.description: As cannabis legalization has become more widespread, retailers are getting increasingly serious about the design and branding of their shops.
item.dc:creator: Anna P. Kambhampaty
item.media:credit: Joe Schmelzer for The New York Times
item.media:description: At Wyllow, a weed store in Los Angeles, a goal is to create a multi-sensory shopping experience that includes a cannabis terpene scent installation and custom LED-lighting that evolves from day to night.

item.title: Reno Is Booming. Some Workers Feel Left Behind.
item.description: Companies are flocking to the Nevada city, but the rising cost of housing, gas and groceries is making daily life a struggle for many who work there.
item.dc:creator: Jordyn Holman and Deanne Fitzmaurice
item.media:credit: Deanne Fitzmaurice for The New York Times
item.media:description: About 8.8 million square feet are under construction in the Reno, Nev., area.

item.title: Herschel Walker’s Polling Dip
item.description: How the Senate race in Georgia is shaking out.
item.dc:creator: Nate Cohn
item.media:credit: Nicole Craine for The New York Times
item.media:description: Herschel Walker.

item.title: High-profile debates took place in Wisconsin and Michigan on Thursday.
item.description: Two debates were hosted in marquee political races in Wisconsin and Michigan, both battleground states. Catch up on what happened.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: From left, the candidates who debated Thursday: Lt. Gov. Mandela Barnes and Senator Ron Johnson, in the Wisconsin Senate race; and Gov. Gretchen Whitmer and Tudor Dixon, in Michigan’s governor race.

item.title: Why Social Security’s Inflation Protection Is Priceless
item.description: Automatically adjusted lifetime income is rare and worth protecting, our columnist says.
item.dc:creator: Jeff Sommer
item.media:credit: Tom Grillo

item.title: I’m Young. Should I Care About Social Security?
item.description: One reason: You pay for it. And, despite what many Americans believe, it’s “definitely a misconception” that it will run out before you retire, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Charlotte Cowles
item.media:credit: Lisa Haney

item.title: For ‘The Great British Baking Show,’ ‘Mexican Week’ Was Not an Accident
item.description: After 12 years, the show’s long, inexorable journey from comfort to cringe is complete.
item.dc:creator: Tejal Rao
item.media:credit: Love Productions/Netflix
item.media:description: The judges and hosts of the “Great British Baking Show” — from left, Paul Hollywood, Prue Leith, Matt Lucas and Noel Fielding — recently encountered significant backlash to the show’s “Mexican Week” episode.

item.title: The L.A. City Council Scandal Shows What Happens When Race Is Everything
item.description: Stop turning public life into a brutal struggle of group against group.
item.dc:creator: David Brooks
item.media:credit: Mario Tama/Getty Images

item.title: Alex Jones Picked on the Wrong People
item.description: This week’s news should have been no surprise to Mr. Jones.
item.dc:creator: Anna Merlan
item.media:credit: Michelle McLoughlin/Reuters

item.title: Rachel Maddow Looks Back on a Wild 14 Years
item.description: The MSNBC anchor discusses her storied career living through history’s grip, and the view of America from her seat.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Ezra Klein Show’
item.media:credit: MSNBC

item.title: This Is How to Put the Supreme Court in Its Place
item.description: Democrats in the 21st Century should not make the same mistake Republicans in the 19th Century did.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie
item.media:credit: Damon Winter/The New York Times

item.title: Biden’s Tough Tech Trade Restrictions on China
item.description: America abandons its sunny view of globalization.
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman
item.media:credit: Ashley Gilbertson for The New York Times

item.title: What A.L.S. and Alzheimer’s Drug Approvals Have in Common
item.description: How to balance patient’s needs with their safety.
item.dc:creator: Alison Bateman-House
item.media:credit: Paola Saliby

item.title: Why That John Fetterman Interview Caused a Furor
item.description: It is our accommodations, often but not exclusively technological in nature, that make it possible for many of us to do our jobs.
item.dc:creator: David M. Perry
item.media:credit: Jeff Swensen for The New York Times

item.title: Xi Jinping and the Perils of Overreach
item.description: His next term could be a rough one for China as problems mount for an inflexible leader.
item.dc:creator: Susan Shirk
item.media:credit: Illustration by E S Kibele Yarman; photograph by JUAN MABROMATA / Contributor via Getty

item.title: The Fear Facer: An Update
item.description: We revisit the 2019 story of Ella Maners, a young girl whose fears were taking over her life — until she went to summer camp.
item.dc:creator: Michael Barbaro, Julia Longoria, Wendy Dorr, Lynsea Garrison, Jazmin Aguilera, Marc Georges, Anita Badejo, MJ Davis Lin, Stella Tan, Alexander Overington, Marion Lozano, Elisheba Ittoop and Brad Fisher
item.media:credit: Robyn Nelson
item.media:description: Ella Maners in 2019 at Fear Facers Summer Camp in Gainesville, Fla.

item.title: Democrats Worry Katie Hobbs Is Stumbling in Arizona’s Governor Race
item.description: Hobbs, the Arizona secretary of state, has often been overshadowed by her Republican opponent, Kari Lake, in one of the country’s closest and most important contests.
item.dc:creator: Blake Hounshell
item.media:credit: Rebecca Noble for The New York Times
item.media:description: Katie Hobbs, the Arizona secretary of state and the Democratic nominee for governor, has declined to debate her Republican rival, Kari Lake.

item.title: How to Get Rid of Bad Breath
item.description: Food choices, oral hygiene habits and certain health conditions can play a role — but there are ways to keep dragon breath in check.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Illustration by Pablo Delcan; Photographs by Getty Images

item.title: Kroger and Albertsons Announce Plan to Merge in $25 Billion Deal
item.description: The deal, an effort to bulk up against deep-pocketed rivals Walmart and Amazon, is likely to invite antitrust scrutiny from regulators.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch and Julie Creswell
item.media:credit: Carlos Bernate for The New York Times
item.media:description: The combined annual revenue of Kroger and Albertsons is close to Walmart’s grocery sales.

item.title: Why New York’s Day Care Centers Are Going Broke
item.description: One Montessori school leader has spent $200,000 of her own money to keep underserved children enrolled in her program.
item.dc:creator: Ginia Bellafante
item.media:credit: Michael Loccisano/Getty Images
item.media:description: Universal pre-K, the signature policy of the de Blasio years, was a great success. Will it be possible to create a similar child care program for younger children?

item.title: Father Joe, Bangkok’s Priest to the Poor, Thrives Among Fellow Outcasts
item.description: For 50 years, the Rev. Joseph Maier has lived in one of the poorest parts of the Thai capital, ministering to Catholics, Buddhists and Muslims alike, and never finding favor with the church hierarchy.
item.dc:creator: Seth Mydans
item.media:credit: Lauren DeCicca for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Rev. Joseph H. Maier visiting a kindergarten class last month at the community center he founded in one of the poorest areas of Bangkok.

item.title: Climate Protesters Throw Soup Over van Gogh’s ‘Sunflowers’
item.description: Two activists attacked the famous painting at the National Gallery, in London.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Just Stop Oil, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The protesters also smeared their hands in glue, and stuck them to the museum’s walls.

item.title: Strength Training Beginners Guide: How to Make the Workout a Habit
item.description: For real this time.
item.dc:creator: Danielle Friedman
item.media:credit: Ryan Frigillana for The New York Times

item.title: Ankle Exercises to Help Strengthen and Prevent Injury
item.description: Ankle instability is often the result of nerve and ligament damage. These exercises can help get you back on, and stay on, your feet.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Fairbank
item.media:credit: Izaiah Johnson for The New York Times

item.title: How to Motivate Yourself to Exercise
item.description: Bundle your incentives. Be flexible. Get some support. Here’s how to get — and stay — motivated.
item.dc:creator: Christie Aschwanden
item.media:credit: Keith E. Morrison for The New York Times

item.title: Is Barefoot Weight Lifting Safe?
item.description: This strength training practice can fortify your feet, but experts warn that it’s not without risk.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Fairbank
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: Is It Possible to Exercise Too Much?
item.description: And if so, how can I tell if I’m overdoing it?
item.dc:creator: Christie Aschwanden
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: What’s That Oddball Conifer? A Japanese Umbrella Pine.
item.description: It may be called a pine, but it isn’t a member of the pine family. And no, those lustrous, oversized needles aren’t plastic.
item.dc:creator: Margaret Roach

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
